abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission is said to have opened an insider trading inquiry to scrutinize unusually robust options trading ahead of the $23 billion takeover of the food company H.J. Heinz.
snippet: The Securities and Exchange Commission is said to have opened an insider trading inquiry to scrutinize unusually robust options trading ahead of the $23 billion takeover of the food company H.J. Heinz.
lead_paragraph: Regulators are scrutinizing unusual trading surrounding the planned $23 billion takeover of the food company H. J. Heinz, raising questions about potential illegal activity in one of the biggest deals in recent memory, a person briefed on the matter said.

headline.main: S.E.C. Looks at Trades a Day Before Heinz Deal
headline.print_headline: S.E.C. Looks At Trades Day Before Heinz Deal

abstract: Wall Street deal makers and chief executives are getting their groove back. | Despite an investigation into suspicious trading, SAC Capital Advisors is holding on to its largest outside investor, the Blackstone Group. | Carl C. Icahn officially has a dog in the Herbalife fight. | Elizabeth Warren grilled top banking regulators in her inaugural appearance as a member of the Senate Banking Committee.
snippet: Wall Street deal makers and chief executives are getting their groove back. | Despite an investigation into suspicious trading, SAC Capital Advisors is holding on to its largest outside investor, the Blackstone Group. | Carl C. Icahn officially ha...
lead_paragraph: THE RETURN OF BIG DEALS  |  Wall Street deal makers and chief executives are getting their groove back. After a fallow few years following the financial crisis, merger activity has roared back to life in the opening weeks of 2013, DealBook’s Peter Lattman writes. On Thursday, Warren E. Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway teamed up with the Brazilian firm 3G Capital to buy H. J. Heinz for $23 billion, as American Airlines and US Airways agreed to merge in an $11 billion deal. Those transactions came on the heels of the $24 billion agreement to take Dell private and the $16 billion deal by Liberty Global to buy Virgin Media.

abstract: The deals of recent weeks have very little to do with the trends that bankers on Wall Street say they believe will drive a new cycle of deal-making.
snippet: The deals of recent weeks have very little to do with the trends that bankers on Wall Street say they believe will drive a new cycle of deal-making.
lead_paragraph: Are we in the middle of a bull run for mergers?

headline.main: A Deal-Making Craze? Yes, With Caveats

abstract: Berkshire Hathaway and 3G Capital announce a blockbuster deal for H.J. Heinz, American Airlines and US Airways announce a merger, and Brooklyn Brewery sets its sights on France.
